reviewText:
The Force Unleashed is a miracle of bad game design. Poor explanation of controls? Check. A tutorial (for throwing stuff with the Force, at least) that comes after the prologue level? Check. Bosses- and regular enemies- that can block attacks, knock you down, use attacks that you can't avoid or block, and make you forget all those neat combos in favor of button-mashing? Check. Seriously, one of the later levels gives you two or three purge troopers (who can knock you down), an AT-ST (which can also knock you down) and an assortment of stormtroopers (who can't knock you down but will constantly interrupt you by shooting you). Any difficulty above Apprentice, on which I still got killed by the aforementioned spam, is unthinkably nightmarish during or after the second boss. Not that the second boss is ever anything but.
There are also insultingly pointless quick-time events. You're given a surprisingly long window for each button press, and if by some perverse miracle you press the wrong button... either you can immediately initiate the QTE again or, if it's in a boss fight, you just get to press the right button. I failed to press X at a moment when doing so would prevent Starkiller from being fatally beaten in a saber lock... and I was just asked to do it again as the saber lock continued. Just let me kill the boss and watch the finisher or something. Sheesh.
The camera is rather irritating to control, though in my experience that's nothing new. Some people have complained about the fact that most of the boss fights have  a fixed camera, and while I understand that it's annoying, I'm actually somewhat glad that for once I don't have to bother with rotating the camera.  You can lock on to enemies, though, so that's a plus.
The game also only has three tilesets. We see Kashyyk in the prologue and in the story proper, we go to Felucia (how I hate Felucia) twice, and two different planets have the junkyard tileset. There might be more instances of this, though. I haven't finished the game.
To try to tie together the disparate complaints in this review, let me tell you about my favorite area in the game: a certain open area on Felucia. It's a clearing with some islands of foliage and weird tentacles that react violently when you shock them (this is probably meant to help you clear out enemies, but it didn't seem too helpful to me), loads of obnoxious Felucian warriors, some large, explosive fruits surrounding the clearing, and not one, not two, but THREE Rancors.
Quick rundown of Felucians: they have bone swords with forcefields that can block your attacks, they have forcefield shields that can block your attacks, they have shamans that can render them invincible, and they have another variant that shoot lasers at you from a staff. There are, as I mentioned, loads of them in this particular stretch of jungle, and they make it nearly impossible to take the necessary time to grab and throw fruits at the Rancors. They also seem to spawn continuously, though I could be wrong about that. Note this: the rushed, out-of-touch or downright sadistic people who made this game give the player an efficient means of dealing with the dangerous enemies in an area and then make that means essentially useless. I had to downgrade from Sith Lord (regular) difficulty to Apprentice (easy) to get through that area. At the point in the game I'm at the player is frequently pit against AT-STs, which are essentially Rancors that can consistently hit from a distance, and either not given any obvious throwables (not that they help against an AT-ST in firing range) or mobbed with stormtroopers.
This is all very tragic, really, because TFU had the potential to be a good game. There are points in the game where I've felt like the overpowered Sith I'm supposed to be, but these are few and far between when all sorts of enemies can block my lightsaber, force push or lightning and then repeatedly knock me over.

reviewText:
The reason why I don't recommend this game is because this game is from the old era of games where gimmicky combat was all about the player either being lucky or exposing some of the cheaper elements of the game in order to triumph.

There are many other choices to make if you support consoles, but unfortunately as a PC user most of the third person action titles with a camera that isn't isometric seems far away from ever happening because of PC being a secondary platform, and because most PC gamers prefer using a keyboard. Games like dragons dogma, dark souls, skyrim, devil may cry, dynasty warriors, toukiden, and eventually God eater and for honor, seem to be the only few types of run around jump action titles that exist with melee combat on the PC genre. However, all of those games have mechanics that will actually support your playstyle, this does not.

Some examples of these bad elements include bosses endlessly countering attacks, randomly losing 40 percent of your health from attacks, missing with your sith thunder attack, faulty attack priority, getting locked into enemy combos, slippery slopes while exploring, bad camera angles, cutscenes everywhere, and a throw system that trumps the combat system because of the ai.

Granted, games of this time have always been full of gimmicks when choosing the hardest available difficulty, however, in action games, it's almost necessary to do so to enjoy the variations of combos the game has to offer. Though the ai makes a point to walk through half of your combo to the point where it feels like you're playing a dragon ball z game, and it's almost an implicit need to throw and blast everything rather than even try to punch anything. That's a big no no if you're trying to make an action game... it'll end up being like dragon age... where mages and archers destroy the game for any type of melee. Moreso with the latter.

It's not a bad game though... the visuals, movement, enemies and effects are still a strong point, the visual fluidity and normal difficulty pacing in the game makes for some of the more fast and curious platform games I've played in the past and adds action from other games that lack the speed or traversal appeal that this game boasts. It's one of the main reasons I've bothered picking it back up despite already playing through most of it on 360. But despite how much I do like the game after I bench some of the more irritating elements, I would never recommend this game to anyone who is looking for a fair and honest challenge. Because let's face it, outside of exploration, the main reason for playing it is to kick butt Jedi style. Not kicking yourself for the game being too cheap to play how you want.

reviewText:
So I bought this game because it was one of the few SW games I hadn't played yet. Heard some good things about it, and it looked decently fun. After all, to me it was Star Wars and that's all I really cared about. Oh boy if only I'd known what I was getting myself into

Right off the bat the first thing I bump into is a bug with the audio. Throughout the game the sounds are glitched and sometimes they don't play. I can get past this, save for the fact that there's no quality to the rest of the game. This has hands down one of the worst combat systems I've played in any other action game. Nevermind the button mashing, as I didn't expect something of the quality of DMC3 with this game. I just wanted a game that was fun to play

But it's not. The gameplay is terrible. The combat is slow and clunky, you get knocked down every single time and have to wait until your character clunkily regains his balance, all the meanwhile he can keep receiving damage. The force powers are underwhelming and they're awkward to use due to the terrible nature of the camera and the controls. The platforming is terrible due to how badly designed the movement system is as there is no proper collision detection and you just slide off round invisible surfaces as if this were a PS1 game.

All bosses are gimmicky and a pain to fight. Since you fight them in arena-shaped areas, the camera view completely changes and now it sits far away from you. Instead of following your character so that you know how you're oriented and can properly move around, the game instead pans out and you have to clumsily move around completely disoriented. The targetting system for using your powers on bosses is completely useless and you have a hard time actually locking onto your target. The areas are filled with hazards that you need to constantly move around or else you're thrown around like a ragdoll losing huge chunks of health at every turn. Combine this with the terrible combat system and the clunky movement and you've got a recipe to disaster

The levels all have been a bore so far due to how you can abuse your force powers to destroy everything instantly, or whenever you're faced with overwhelming odds you can always just find a way to cheese fights because the AI is braindead. On top of that the game looks ugly and bland, and you can't even appreciate the cutscenes due to the aforementioned audio problems

Overall I wouldn't recommend this game at all. Luckily I got it during the holiday sale, but even then I still regret ever purchasing it

reviewText:
This game has a great idea with a fantastic story, but the gameplay itself is executed terribly. The controls feel awkward, the force powers aren't as fluid as they could be. Enemies can hit you while you're on the ground which can be very frustrating as health does not automatically regenerate. The worst part of the gameplay is the terribly done boss fights. Each one gives you a terrible camera view and lightsaber fights are not nearly as cool as they could have been. If you even try to swing your lightsaber at the boss, they just defelect it with the same annoying animation every single time. Most of the more difficult enemies just require you to spam force push/lighting with follow up short lightsaber attacks and they're just not fun at all. The worst part of the game was probably in the last few levels where you're tasked with destroying a ship using force push powers and the objects never travel in the direction your aiming, making it very difficult to take out enemy TIE fighters. Another pretty stupid part of the game was one of the levels bosses. The developers thought it would be cool for you to fight Darth Maul, so they had your comic relief robot hologram character randomly fight you in the middle of the mission. It just came off as lazy and frustrating.

The graphics are expected for a game from 2009. Unfortunetly, the game is a pretty obvious console port, with a painful 30fps lock that keeps the game from running as fluid as it could. The lighting and textures are average but what really stands out is the fantastic physics engine. While the controls are terrible making it difficult to do, it is still awesome to be able to pull objects off the walls and throw them at your enemies just like you would see in the movies.

The story is this games only saving grace. It takes place between the original trilogy and the newer prequel series with Darth Vader hunting down the last remanents of the Jedis in the galaxy. You play the roll of a new apprentice Starkiller" who is tasked with going to planets (all of which are locations Star Wars fans will recognize) to kill a bunch of locals and hunt down the jedi hiding there. The cutscenes are done very well with great voice acting and new original characters that fit perfetly into the Star Wars universe. The scenes even have that cheap looking transitional fade that the original movies had which really shows the attention to detail in making what appears to be a real Star Wars movie. The ending does feature two endings depending on what you do

reviewText: For any Star wars gamer, this game is an exciting experience. You begin as Darth Vader himself! A fantastic nod to the fan community, and many people who think Vader is badass, and march around in home made costumes depecting the Sith Lord to stunnning quality. Discover an epic plot masterminded by Vader himself, and help him achieve his goals...or do you have goals of your own? Customize your own lightsaber with various crystal colors, and even special crystals that boost force powers or saber damage. Fight a variety of enemies and take advantage of your environment in strategic and out-of-the-box ways. Every level plays differently each time with a sweet AI that provides a good deal of variety and unexpected turns.

reviewText:
I liked playing this game, although there are upsides and downsides:

+ the story was pretty good and  I was kind of curious what would happen next
+ special lightsaber parts, but:
- changing the Lightsaber Color actually only changes its appearance
+ Style of the fighting system, but:
- technique of the fighting system (Autoaim is sometimes malicious)
-  Really bad recovery, if you accidentially get hit by a missile while enemies surround you you might actually die
because you take damage even while lying on the ground and he takes ages to get up again
- Button mashing suffices most of the time to kill most enemies, including some bosses
+ Interesting Bossfights, but:
- more or less trial and error, which seemed unfair sometimes so I had some difficulties against some and died 4 or 5 times until I got their pattern  Darth Maul, Fight against Vader where he stands in the middle and throws rubbish at you, same with the Imperator, and I also experienced some difficulty against the girl with the double nunchuck sabers (forgot her name, sorry)  , some of the other bosses were too easy where you can just spam one Combo to kill them
+ the graphics were good (considering its age)
+ original sound
- bad trashmob AI
- some minor bugs, like music not playing, standing on top of platforms where you shouldn't be able to get to, AT-ST's where you are able to stand on their feet and do infinite combos in mid-air
- only 5h to play through on medium difficulty

I still liked playing it! Would I recommend it? If you like Star Wars, definitely, even if you would only play it on easy
to experience the story. But if you are looking for a technically flawless game with dozens of hours of gameplay and an insane fighting system, this game might actually disappoint you.
I heard SW:TFU2 is better. Gonna play it now :)

-  Really bad recovery, if you accidentially get hit by a missile while enemies surround you you might actually die
because you take damage even while lying on the ground and he takes ages to get up again
- Button mashing suffices most of the time to kill most enemies, including some bosses
+ Interesting Bossfights, but:
- more or less trial and error, which seemed unfair sometimes so I had some difficulties against some and died 4 or 5 times until I got their pattern  Darth Maul, Fight against Vader where he stands in the middle and throws rubbish at you, same with the Imperator, and I also experienced some difficulty against the girl with the double nunchuck sabers (forgot her name, sorry)  , some of the other bosses were too easy where you can just spam one Combo to kill them
+ the graphics were good (considering its age)
+ original sound
- bad trashmob AI
- some minor bugs, like music not playing, standing on top of platforms where you shouldn't be able to get to, AT-ST's where you are able to stand on their feet and do infinite combos in mid-air
- only 5h to play through on medium difficulty

I still liked playing it! Would I recommend it? If you like Star Wars, definitely, even if you would only play it on easy
to experience the story. But if you are looking for a technically flawless game with dozens of hours of gameplay and an insane fighting system, this game might actually disappoint you.
I heard SW:TFU2 is better. Gonna play it now :)

reviewText:
I want to like this game. It has so much potential. And sometimes when you're playing it there are moments that are really, really fun. When you're jumping from Stromtrooper to Stormtrooper, your lightsaber combos are flowing beautifully, you're force throws are on point, you feel really powerful. The close you can ever feel to being a real Jedi.

But unfortunately those moments are too far between. What could be epic gameplay is, more often than not, hampered by shotty targeting, bad camera angles, weird boss fights that block everything so you can't really use any good combos or slick moves, annoying sequences where you will get hit by an attack that knocks you down, and it takes your character so long to stand back up that you're hit by another one immediately, and this repeats until you die while you scream at your monitor. Seriously for being a badass Jedi, this guy stands up at a speed that would make my grandpa laugh. For every time you epicly force grab something and throw it at an enemy, there are three times where you force grab something and for some reason throw it in a completely random direction. Or when you try and force lightning someone, and for some reason you force lightning the air right beside them while they stand there and look at you like you're crazy.

The game is difficult. But not in a fun way. I like a game that is a challenge. If I make a mistake, punish me (didn't realize how dirty that sounded until I said it out loud). But this game isn't difficult in that way. It's difficult in a lot of the enemies have slow, repetitive unblockable attacks that knock you down over and over and over again. It's difficult where the boss just randomly becomes invincible/blocks everything you have so you just have to wait for him to let you start attacking again. Really any lightsaber duel feels less like a duel and more like you using force lightning and just running away because that's significantly more effective than actually using your lightsaber due to the enemy blocking all your attacks and all of his attacks being unblockable. It has entirely too many jumping puzzles for a game with a bad camera and an erratic, unreliable double jump.

Little things like that that should have never made it through any kind of QA testing.

The DNA of a great game is there. But it needed another 6 months of polishing before release, at least. This is on the top of my games that didn't live up to their immense potential" list.

And that's not even counting how bad of a PC port this is. Straight port. 30fps. No extra graphic enhancements. Nothing to take advantage of being on a PC. Just seems lazy.

I played the game all the way through because of those brief moments of fun. But I would say I only really enjoyed myself about %30 of the time
date: the other %70 I was just more annoyed and frustrated than anything else."

reviewText:
Star Wars - The Force Unleashed. This game is fun. Great even, for a while. This game basically links Star Wars Episodes 3 and 4 together, by way of telling the creation of the Rebellion, and how Leia became a forerunner of it, etc. It has a cool story line, and is generally just fun. I don't know, this is the first game of its kind I've played, I think.

As for being a console port, my review for this game definitely goes down.

As I've just said, this game was a console port. That means that it was made for the consoles first, and then converted to pc code to be played there (even though technically it's first made with pc code, depending on how they made it, I digress). One of the missions in this game, has you -SPOILER ALERT- take a Star Destroyer out of space and into the ground.

The reason why I'm mad about that, is because of the gameplay part of that. You have to spam your mouse up and/or down to get it into position, as well as use a or d to move it laterally, and then when it's in place you can bring it down. Well, unless you know that you don't have to frantically move your mouse, you're probably going to end up destroying it accidentally, by way of friction. Also, even when you know you don't have to do that, it's still very difficult to do. I couldn't.



Don't buy this game on PC. Buy it on console, if you still can, or watch it, if you're interested. It's a good game, with an okay port, until you get to that mission - somewhere midway through the game I think.

reviewText:
What can I say about force unleashed? This is a hard one to review because I have not been able to finish this. I'm not one to claim to be a great video game player. I play most of my linear style games on easy / medium settings and I look for more plot and direction of the story. A good story can often overcome some bugs and glitches or bad game mechanics.

Not with this game. This is a bad game. Its not often I will say this but this is a game to avoid. When you are introduced to the story, there is so much hope and promise, But unfortunately the rest of the game gets in the way.

The gameplay is unpolished. The mechanics are boring and repetitive. What looks like it could be a well thought out fight mechanic quickly turns into button mashing adventure of whack a mole, as computer controlled oponents constantly spawn and run at you. The AI is terrible as most enemies will stand there and take it. UNfortunately, The Enemy AI, being extremely weak is compensated for by boss fight mechanics that are repeitively annoying. We're not talking about, 5-10 moves that are varied up. Most enemy bosses will come at you with no more than 2-3 moves. Often will just stun / slam you into a corner or invisible wall (more on thos later!) and repeat that for 20 or so seconds while you watch in disbelief unable to even interact with your character. Many enemies have artificial buffs to try and counter you. They are extremely one dimension. SOme are immune to force. Some autoblock lightsabers. Some can't get shoved, some cant get electrocuted. it seems artificial and fake.

The gameplay itself is extremely 1 directional. You follow the path forward at all points. This isn't necessarily bad for a platformer. I tend to like directed story games. But this one isn't good. You're often rudely interrupted while running for cutscenes that are abrupt and out of place. The paths look like you might have multiple ways of going, but you quickly find that they are just invisible walls and that your direction is set no matter what.

The biggest offender though of the game mechanics? the overuse, constantly abusing you with QUicktime events. If it's a non standard enemy. So, Any AT_T walkers, rancor, or the like, which come more and more frequently as you progress, will end with a Quicktime event. You will do thousands of them. And they're not short either. many of them taking 20-30 seconds of watching you kill the enemy with some completely arbitrary, pre-scripted event that has nothing to do with the way you fight in game and acts as a complete disconnect to the battle system.

Then you get to the worst boss battle in any star wars game I can ever recall. Perhaps one of my least liked boss battles ever. The Star Destroyer. Combine all that is wrong in this game, add in broken gameplay mechanics, incorrect instructions on screen and constant waves of enemies that are timed on purpose to prevent you from finishing this boss quickly, I just gave up.

And just when you thought it can't get worse. it does. The Camera system is frustrating. it does not always follow you smoothly from behind and during many fights, you will find it swinging widly around, changing how your character responds to your button presses. Then Boss fights introduces brand new camera mechanics. It attempts to emulated a 1v1 side scrolling fighter, but horribly. The camera finds a fixed position off in the distance and just shows you the map" you are to fight in. Except
date: the controls don't lend well to this view and you will find yourself runing into walls and posts and getting stuck with things in your feet between you and your foe
recommended: making most boss fights a fight against the camera

reviewText:
One of the poorest quality PC ports available on Steam.

Control and video options have to be set in a launcher outside the game, and the options available in-game are barebones, not even including an option for subtitles in-game, let alone cutscenes.

Combat is unnecessarily difficult. The lock-on key is useless, and force powers are extremely difficult to aim. Lifted enemies and objects fly in crazy directions that don't seem to take any input from keys pressed or mouse movements. Boss battles add to the frustration, as bosses can shrug off force powers and lightsaber attacks with impunity, and often seem to be completely invincible during scripted movement and combat sequences.

Even on my relatively nice gaming rig (GTX 680 x2, i7 3820 @3.6Ghz, 32Gbs RAM) this game suffers constant stuttering, and  odd split-second flashes of other scenes when using some force powers and lightsaber attacks.

Just from a technical standpoint this game is a failure, but the ridiculous (and unfortunately canon) storyline only pushes this pile of garbage further into the forgetful" realm of gaming. It's hard to choke down even as an avid Star Wars fan.

-5/10"

reviewText:
This is a shining example of a console port done wrong. The controls feel awkward with a keyboard and mouse, and are often downright frustrating (Lightning goes through the legs of an ATST but you aren't actually hitting it), boss battles for some reason force you into a different camera perspective and are generally more frustration than fun, and there are way, way, way too many quicktime events. In fact, you can't kill most large enemies without executing one. They aren't difficult, but they aren't especially fun, either.

Further, the characters are bland and uninteresting, the main character is a gigantic Mary Sue, and there are many ridiculous aspects (breathing and talking in vacuum, a shapechanging, Force-using droid??????) that make it hard to stomach. The enemy types are not all that varied; in fact, very few require you to change tactics to deal with them.

In conclusion, don't waste your money.

reviewText:
Gameplay- The Force Unleashed's main goal was to make the player feel like they are a sith lord, being able to use different, powerful force based attacks. In that aspect the game delivers, but this all gets boring after a while, as combat is rediculousy easy, I'm sure anyone can beat the game without upgrading too much. Combat is not satifying at all, as you find yourself killing waves and waves of enemies without trying. During the second part of the game different variants of storm troopers arrive, in order to kill them you have to use a particular technique, this gets boring FAST. Most boss fights are pretty lame as well, as many of the bosses limit or restrict your uses of the force powers, or they require constant button mashing. This makes the boss fights boring and not rewarding, a good example of a well designed boss fights would be the colossuses in Shadow Of The Colossus, all the bosses were unique. Mr Freeze from Batman Arkham city would be another one, as Freeze adapts to your attacks, evades, and movements. It was a multi step fight with out lame QTE sequences or out of placed cutsences, which were everywhere in The Force Unleashed.

Story- The story is mediocre, which is really sad because the Star Wars universe is very interesting. The main character Galen Marek is very dull, and has no emotions, a good comparison to Marek would be Connor from Assasin's Creed III, which is not a good thing. Other characters are not much better etheir, everyone just seemed so boring and unteresting. The missions are not much better ethier, they all feel the same, as you slaughter waves and waves of enemies. level design was flawed, as many of the levels looked very similar and were boring to play through. The Force Unleashed has two endings, both were terrible, the good ending being a little bit better than the bad one, but thats not saying much at all. In the end you find yourself not being able to make any decisions as the game does that for you, but it really does not matter as the build up and the characters along the way were boring and painfully average.

Overall opinion- The Force Unleashed is game made only for Star Wars fans, if you want a hack and slash game, go ahead and buy DMC, it's much better than this. If you desire a game that explores the lore and mythos of Star Wars, this not the game for you etheir. The people that would enjoy the Force Unleashed would be hardcore star wars fans and people that want a easy game where you feel like a god. At the end of the day Star Wars The Forced Unleashed is a disappointing  game, it could have been great but instead it fell short, The Force Unleashed is not a terrible game, but it's not a good one etheir.

Rating- 6/10 Average game.

reviewText:
The game's main selling point is its physics engine. It combines Havok, Euphoria (of GTA4 fame), and DMM to rather remarkable results. And for those of you who don't know, DMM is a more in depth material modelling engine. The idea being that you get objects which bend and break like their real world counterparts. Glass shatters, wood splinters, metal bends, and plants swing. And it's remarkably effective. Often it adds to the wreckless destruction your jedi powers leave in their wake, as all sorts on the sidelines gets caught in your wrath. And at other times, it's used to open doors. Two layers of steel blocking the way? Not a problem, just punch it out of the way!

However it's not an open ended game. It ultimately has you navigate a linear path, which is fine. But in order to do this, it has to put up immovable barriers to keep you there. Which rather horribly juxtaposes all that dynamic damage they have going on. In fact, in order to make sure the game's still completable, there's a lot of indestructable level geometry. The only bridge across a chasm won't break, for instance. But next to the impressive DMM magic, it feels astonishingly cheap. At times, that damage engine can just feel like a gimick you get brief glimpses of, as some areas make very sparing use of it, so the game falls back on raw gameplay for enjoyment.

Which brings me to the biggest problem I have with this game. The levels feel very drawn out and artificially lengthened, and get tedious quickly. Especially as fighting enemies isn't particularly fun. The infantry type enemies don't pose any real threat, leaving you only with the choice of which force power or lightsaber combo to kill them with, coupled with how cruel your sense of humor is. The boss fights are more interesting, with moves like blocking suddenly becoming useful, but even those drag on enormously.

On top of that, there's a few issues with the PC version. It's locked to 30fps and the lack of detail leaves a lot of the game looking rather bleak and apocalyptic in ways it's clearly not supposed to.

As with many others I bought this because I am a Star Wars fan. I saw it had mixed reviews but I took a chance. I figured at very least it would be like a next gen version of Jedi Academy. Nah. Just, nah.

It is a badly made game. It is not fun, the controls are terrible and the menu layout (yeah, not really something a developer could mess up) is so irritating to navigate.

So I really don't recommend this game. You are seriously better off doing something else. This is NOT and enjoyable game.

reviewText:
I'll keep this short.
The force unleashed is an absolutely brilliant game for the first run however doesn't have much replayability, any complaints about how the game is bad by people who are replaying the game are likely because the story is horrible to re-play to the point where you find yourself noticing the smallest details wrong with the game. which is why even though I found the same issues this is a bad review not because of those issues but instead because there are No Graphics options.
Allow me to restate that actually. there are three graphics options.

Brightness

Resolution

High Detail

And High detail is a freaking tick box.

Essentially because of this if you buy the game and have some kind of graphical issue, well you bought the wrong game and if those three tiny options don't fix it for you too bad, you're on your own.

reviewText: Okay, so this game was great on the consoles, and it's great on the PC, too.  However, the PC port is literally just a data-dump from a blu-ray disc.  The installation is 30 gigabytes.  Yes, you read that correctly.  The game is also not optimized for keyboard use whatsoever, so I recommend plugging in an Xbox 360 controller.  If you have the patience for the insane install size and the practically mandatory controller requirement, Force Unleashed is a pretty damn solid combo-based hack-n-slash RPG.  The extra content in the Sith Edition is cool too, mainly because you can MURDER LUKE SKYWALKER.

reviewText:
I just came back to this game after a year's hiatus and got an abrupt reminder of why I stopped playing it in the first place. I just about had an aneurysm out of sheer rage while trying to finish a level I gave up on before. Lemme put things in a list.

Story: Well, it's not terrible. I've seen worse writing plenty of times. It just isn't very grabbing to me. Don't take my opinion on this, though; I've never put much thought into the backstory of the Star Wars franchise.

World Design/Graphics: About what I expected. Looks like a Star Wars game. Some of the expressions and character models look like they were made in Garry's Mod, but it's bearable.

Physics: RUN. RUN FAR AWAY. The physics engine in this game is just god-awful. Platforming is a pain; accurately judging a jump is like trying to throw a ball whose density is constantly fluctuating. Some of the terrain is horridly rough, with smooth ground being un-walkable in random spots. Of course, none of this helps while fighting. And speaking of that...

Combat: The control scheme for fighting isn't too bad. Basic combat maneuvers, such as jumping, slashing, lighting, and dodging are all on natural-feeling buttons. The AI, however, is an absolute NIGHTMARE. Enemies will constantly gang up on you, slapping you around like a pinball in combos that are infuriatingly hard to get out of: blocking and dashing while being hit are impossible. And when the guys right next to you aren't hitting you, the ones halfway across the map are picking you off with impossibly accurate potshots that must be either swatted away by the auto-deflect feature (which has about a 2% success rate) or deflected manually by holding the block button, meaning you can't do ANYTHING ELSE. Which leads to you getting beat over the skull by all those guys right next to you. Crowd control is unlocked about halfway through the game, and DUMPS your force energy gauge. No spamming the Get away from me!" button.


My reccommendation: Steer clear of this game. It's not worth the pain and suffering."

reviewText:
So much wrong here.

The controls feel like you‚Äôre spinning round an action figure rather than somebody with any weight. You find yourself being constantly being thrown around like a ragdoll and most of my deaths seemed to come from being shunted off a platform, resulting in a frustrating return to the last checkpoint.

Actually the platforming in general is just annoying. The game sticks to the Star Wars universe‚Äôs famous lack of health and safety regulations, so any false step will send you plummeting down a chasm. The camera is less than helpful here and there‚Äôs an obscene number of invisible walls placed seemingly at random (jumping towards a bridge, hitting an invisible wall mid-air and sliding down into the mouth of Sarlacc was a particularly ignoble end).

The story is nonsense with a painfully bland protagonist. You are meant to be uber powerful but even your force powers are unsatisfying to use, when using force grip it feels like you are wobbling an object in to place rather than showing any mastery. The only time you actually do something impressing is in the numerous quick time sequences with pop up to disrupt any sort of flow in the game.

Oh and that Star Destroyer sequence from the trailer.. it‚Äôs one of the most of the most painfully terrible bits of gameplay I‚Äôve experienced.

reviewText:
The Force Unleashed is a game where you take... hold, on, let me start over, I've already ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ed this up and called it a game. The Force Unleashed is a franchise-themed BDSM simulator where you play the part of a hapless consumer who pays a monolithic giant to hold you down against the floor and violate you repeatedly.

The Force Unleashed is a great example of what happens when none of the developers communicate in any way. First you have the nerdy tech people like myself who start drooling in their trousers when they think of all of the things you could do with a physics-heavy engine designed around the use of Force powers. They brought ground-breaking technology like Digital Molecular Matter, which allows materials like metal or wood to deform or shatter in dynamic, realistic ways when you do something like Force-push them or slam a stormtrooper into them, or Euphoria, an AI engine which allows those stormtroopers to reach out and grab on to nearby objects in a vain attempt to stop you from flinging them around like a screaming hackey-sack. Unfortunately, the tech people never communicated with the rest of the team, so their fancy tech doesn't really get used at all and the engine is essentially wasted. The tech people also didn't communicate with REALITY, and actually told the general public that the game would only be released on consoles because PCs weren't powerful enough to handle their physics engine. Somehow this didn't stop them from releasing the game on the Wii.

Next are the level designers, who were busy constructing their linear set pieces. Apparently they were too caught up trying to make outdoor environments feel like narrow hallways to speak with the tech team, and didn't even find out about the fancy Digital Molecular Matter system until just before release, the result being that there is about one conspicuously-placed object that actually uses the system in each level. We can also see that the level designers didn't actually watch the films, because in The Force Unleashed the Death Star consists entirely of an interlocking grid of gigantic hangar bays.

The gameplay designers were apparently never told that they were working on a Star Wars property at all, and so they worked from the offset under the model that every enemy should have exactly one weakness, and that each enemy should have a different weakness, apparently not knowing that your character is always holding a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ING LIGHTSABER.

Let's look at this lightsaber issue further. One of the core game design problems faced by every team designing a Star Wars game that includes lightsabers is that the lightsaber quite obviously should be a one-hit kill weapon, but unlimited-use one-hit kill weapons don't usually make for the best game design. Therefore, the designers always have to find some way not to let lightsabers effortlessly carve through all opposition, either by encouraging ranged combat or by limiting the damage of lightsabers for gameplay purposes.

TFU, however, is set between the three Star Wars films and George Lucas's parody prequels; we see claerly in the films that no one has lightsaber-proof armor. In TFU, every later enemy has a sword or shield or armor that is completely 100% lightsaber-proof. In TFU the only difference between a lightsaber and a pointy stick is that a stick doesn't require batteries. Well, I suppose there is also the fact that a lightsaber never gets dull; I wish I could say the same of the gameplay.

It's ironic that in a game where it seems that 100% of the effort went into graphics and gameplay, the gameplay is really quite terrible. As previously mentioned, the lightsaber is really quite useless and you are only able to kill enemies with Force powers. While this doesn't sound bad on paper, in reality each enemy is only weak to exactly one thing, and so for the most part combat alternates between guessing which power is going to kill a new type of enemy, and long sections of fighting that same type of enemy over and over and over in the same exact way. Wait a minute, I thought this game was supposed to encourage creativity?

The only enemies you are given true freedom against are the hapless standard stormtroopers, who fart their blasters ineffectually at you until you go barelling through them or pick them up with Force grip and bash them around a bit. Since the basic stormtrooper is the only opportunity you have to really have fun with grip and push, they are actually given quite a lot of durability, so you can sadistically bash them back and forth between two walls like a future serial killer swinging a squirrel between two trees by the tail. This is fun at first, but if you aren't actually a future serial killer, after a while you actually start to feel bad for the poor stormtrooper who was just doing his job until you decided to smack him around like an unwanted baby at a post-delivery abortion clinic.

Of course, making you scream in rage at all of the enemies who are immune to ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ING LIGHTSABERS wasn't sufficiently sadistic for these developers. As the game goes on, you start running into more and more enemies whose primary weapon is a homing blast that knocks you over, and whose rate of fire is exactly equal to the amount of time it takes you to stand back up. By the Death Star, when you are fighting gigantic killer robots and stormtroopers with cloaking devices who all somehow disappeared from the Empire's arsenal before A New Hope, you will be facing thirty enemies at once who all have a homing missile that knocks you down for exactly the length of time it takes to fire another homing missile, and you'll start to feel like the cheerleader who told the entire football team to have their way with her at once. The game turns into a screaming ragefest of dodging around endless hanger bays killing a single stormtrooper every thirty seconds when you happen to have the luck to land directly behind him between jumps, until by the end of the nightmarish ordeal you are a heavy drinker and need 5 years of therapy.

If you aren't convinced that the game" design is balanced around sado-masochism

reviewText:
Writing here on 05 Dec 2015.
Everything is wrong with this game, avoid it. Spoend your time and money on a cheap excellent indie game like Invisible Inc. Don;t waste your time on this game, go play something else.

* Combat is repetitive, just hack and slash.
* No skill required in combat.
* No story,
* No character progression.
* No loot to collect.
* No weapons dropped by enemies.
* No weapon pickups.
* No loot in destroud boxes or objects.
* Linear path, just follow the dot, no alternative routes.
* Console port with no PC specific additions. Framerate loecked at 30 frmaes per second (fps) is a disgrace to PC gamers.
* No tradeables with other NPCs.
* Pre-rendered video, Full motion video cut-scenes.
* Bland levels with lots of brown, dark brown and dark colors.
* Repetitive scenery.
*(Enemy) difficulty increases by increasing the number of enemies.
* Enemies rush up to you and all you have to do is cut  'em down.
* No skill based combat. If your upgrade for 'skill points' was not right you'll take much longer to defeat an enemy, whereas with a game for example Metal Gear Revengeance one could defeat an enemy on skill.
* It is totally possible to speed run through whole sections/levels, avoiding combat.
* Gfx is horrible console ported, even for 2008 standard. A digrace to PC gamers.
* Plays like an arcade coin-up game, but the endless version.
* DirectX9 game not compatible with my LG 3D displays.
* Horrible framerate, only 30 fps. According to Steam forumsa this was how the game was designed to run, framerate locked.
* Played with a wireless XBOX360 controller on PC.

Don't waste your time on this, go play something else. I have invested a lot of my precious time in this game. I knew I shoul've played Invisble Inc, or Endless Legend or  Withcher 3 instead... but now I'm this far I might as well finish this.

reviewText:
This game is disappointing. I played this game on the PS3 and Wii. If you have a console, buy it on the console (even on the Wii it's a lot more fun). This is a terrible port to the PC and I'm very very disappointed.
Cons:
-Locked on 30fps
-Loading screen for everything
-Loading takes a long time
-Only singleplayer (on console there was a fighting mode)
-Feels choppy due to the frame limit
-Shift + TAB Steam overlay glitches during cutscenes
-Very boring when playing with Keyboard and Mouse
-Repetitive
-Awkward Camera position during boss fights
-Background graphics look like crap
-Why can't i play as Juno Eclipse?

Pros (as experienced from this PC version only)
-Not so awful visuals for a third person game
-Decent physics
-Good storyline
-Good character development and amount of characters
-Cheat codes
-A lot of costumes
-A lot of force combos
-Many different map design and you go on a lot of different planets

Overall this game is not so great on the PC. You can play with a controller, but still, you're playing with 30 fps so why not play this on console instead. Besides, you can go to gamestop, get a $5 pre-owned Force Unleashed instead. If you don't own a console and you want this game, just don't get it at full price. I got mine for $6.60 instead of $20. If you think youre computer can't even play this game above 25 fps, then I guess it's ok. But I built a gaming PC just so I can play a crap port on 30 fps.

reviewText:
Frustratingly clunky, slow and clumsy mechanics and controls make you feel like you're controlling an autistic child with a toy lightsaber rather than the apprentice of one of the most badass siths in the Star Wars universe. Enemy types usually progress as follows: 1. Run-of-the-mill goon 2. Guy that strengthens run-of-the-mill goons 3. Bigger, more powerful run-of-the-mill goon with different colour scheme 4. A whole group of these bigger, more powerful run-of-the-mill goons that effectively jump on you and take turn ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing you in the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• until you die.

What makes it worse is that this all-powerful sith apprentice you play as takes 10 minutes to get up after being knocked down, so when swarmed by these big groups of enemies you'll often have no chance to actually fight back. You don't actually feel like you have control of what's going on due to the bad controls and horrible game design.

The only things good about this game are the lore, the character design, and some of the locales.

Avoid this game if you can, you'll just end up bashing your keyboard or controller into oblivion.

reviewText: 6/10\nThis feels and plays like a reskinned Dynasty Warriors with a few new mechanics added. The lightsaber use and combo is reminiscent of the aforementioned games, but there's a few new bits that are truly great. I personally love this game, because I enjoy crushing storm troopers against the wall, or smashing the airlock and watching rebels get sucked out. It is, however, incredibly repetitive, and the novelty gets old. I pushed through the glitchy physics, the ugly levels and the poor performance because the AI was very responsive and fun to destroy, and the force powers were just fun to use. The levels are very linear, however, and the port is very poor. The camera controls poorly, and the control scheme is terrible (but if you change it, the QTE prompts don't change). Overall, it felt like a quick cash-in (even though it wasn't), but was still enjoyable FOR ME, because I love this crap. Not everyone does.

reviewText:
It's a port from a console, and it's not a very good one either.
Default 30 fps lock, altough it can be modded to be 60 fps.
Menu navigation is not supported for mouse, and the keyboard layout cannot be changed.
Option menu is extremely limited, for changing the graphics you have to tick a single checkbox.
Menu graphics are obviously meant for consoles, but for PC screens, they're way too huge. (And a pain to navigate)

The game CAN get enjoyable at some parts, but most of the time it feels tiresome to play it. The sore need for a save after a risky, long battle can get especially tiresome, since if you die after the battle, you will be spawned back to the last checkpoint.

This especially comes up when fighting bosses. Just about to kill a boss in your last breath, but only manage to die and start it almost all over again.
Bosses are a spam to play, sometimes even outright annoying with the limited saving capabilities you have, and are sometimes even unfair. (ex. You can only hit the boss once per combo, while the boss can punch through your defences and ruthlessy spam it)

If you like QTE's you might actually like this one a lot.

TL;DR Game portrays you as a powerful jedi and falls on spam tactics and QTEs.

reviewText:
Finally finished this little gem of a game which I put off playing for sooooo long.

First of It has some issues, but nothing really game breaking (for me anyway). I loaded this up set it to full hd 1080p graphics are all set to the max, xbox 360 controller supported sat back and played away like a good little Jedi. The game ran perfectly with no major issues at all nothing game breaking, maybe a few random bad bits of level design but nothing that can't be avoided in the first place. The combat was good, a little stiff and sometimes sluggish especially when standing back up after being knocked down and then getting knocked down straight away and to have that repeat 3 or 4 times is very annoying, but not game breaking.

I had an issue on the last level of the game where my sound was missing i could hear slight lightsabre effects but everything else was missing, but this was cured when i downloaded the fixed files from the forum and took seconds to do and was easy to do.

The game itself is alright nothing spectacular it reminded me of Devil May Cry meets Star Wars, its a lot of hack and slash but with force powers and cool lightsabres. You dont use any pistols or ranged weapons other than force powers and throwing of the lightsabre, so dont expect to use rifles etc because you cant. There is a basic but effective leveling up system for your character and the force powers, you can also collect crystals for your sabre to change colour and to add perks to your weapon. These can be found through the levels and by completing various challenged throughout the game.

The game can be frustrating and sometimes lacks proper intruction but nothing major i found and completed all objectives/side missions and enjoyed doing so. One thing I would recommend is that you take breaks when playing this game i spanned it over 3 nights playing for a couple of hours at a time. I did that because its repetetive the same enemies over and over some with added powers/abilities and the odd mini boss before the inevitable end level boss.

That brings me onto the next point i had, Bosses, they didnt seem very tough at all, in fact i found the mini-boss battles with the AT-ST and others that wont be mentioned were a lot tougher at points during the game. The bosses seemed to be over in a few minutes and a lot of them were defeated the exact same way as the previous one but because they were so short i wasnt too fussed.

Now the music, the music. What can i say we all know what the Soundtrack to anything Star Wars is gonna sound like and this game does not fail in providing us with the well known star wars classics. They really do make the game feel more epic than it actually is, i was enjoying my lightsabre massacre with the epic star was soundtrack playing in tempo to the slaying of many, many clone troopers. I would say the soundtrack alone made me enjoy this game more than i should of.

Graphics - I was running it in 1080p as stated earlier with everything set the to max. It ran perfectly not graphical issues at all it looks quite nice for an old'ish game. The only issue i had was the terrible camera angles in various parts of the game but once again not game breaking.

Overall -  There is little in the way of storyline to keep you going it was ok the cutscenes were great, music spot on, graphics were good for the age of the game, QTE was a little annoying with little time to react to some. The only issue i had was with the sound glitching out on the last level but i fixed that so overall i give this game  7/10, could be better but could also be a lot worse, if you are a Star Wars fan and you also like Devil May Cry hack and slash action then this might be the game for you, just dont expect next gen gaming physics or graphics, but what you do get is a few hours of fun.

reviewText:
The Force Unleashed is a great game, if a little akward to control at times.  The game really shows how badass jedi/sith can be, and is great for stress relief.

My only two complaints are that (1) the game can be difficult to control in combat (you feel knockback way more than some enemies, and can easily get stun locked at times), and (2) the DLC (included in teh Ultimate Sith Edition) feels very separate from the game itself.  The DLC isn't added into the game itself, to allow you to continue levelling up and such in new missions, but instead are three new options when you start a new game, providing you a pre-levelled character to use.

Overall, though, it's a great game, and definitely one I'd recommend to all Star Wars fans.

(PS, if my low game time seems suspicious, it's because I put most of my time into this game on my console, and only recently purchased it for Steam)

reviewText:
I'm not a huge fan of the yes/no system. Can this game be fun? Yes. Will it be frustrating? YES. Would you be missing out if you never played it? Probably not.

There's something enjoyable about this game and getting to use force powers in an excessive way. I enjoyed it on my Wii and I'm enjoying it now.

However, this game is not a very well made game. Level design is not good, enemies are either too easy or stunlock you until you die, checkpoints are not close enough together and you will ALWAYS be fighting the camera. I probably wouldn't play this without a USB gamepad. The controls are not tight at all and it's hard to get your character to do what you want him to do. You will fall off of edges a lot because the platforming is terrible. There are QTEs at the end of boss fights.

Personally, this game feels like it has a spectacle-fighter sort of vibe. Except, it lacks almost everything that makes a spectacle fighter good. If done correctly, this game could have been amazing.

The graphics are pretty good (aside from the cutscenes). But honestly, nothing dates this game more than its terrible control and camera issues.

Overall, I think the game is fun, despite its shortcomings. I would probably only get this game at a heavily discounted price though. This is a bargin-bin game (which is where I bought my Wii version). It is good fun for that kind of game. But I find myself setting the game down at least once every 30 minutes because of how frustrating it can be. Unlike something like Dark Souls, this game controls so sloppily that you do not blame yourself, you blame this poorly made game.

reviewText:
Frustrating and stiff controls*, repetitive combat, one-dimensional characters, annoying enemies, unnecessary quick time events, artificially long boss fights. And knockback, don't even get me started on knockback. Very little time spent in between levels; you grind your way through a linear level, kill the boss, watch a brief cutscene and are immediately dropped into the next mission. Story is mediocre, visuals are pretty good by 2009 standards, but the textures can be pretty ugly at times. Almost too much of a reliance on mattes makes anything not in your immediate vicinity look flat and motionless. One of the better looking Star Wars games out there, though, but it's also one of the only recent ones.

If you're a really big Star Wars fan, grab it during the summer sale. Otherwise, stick with better hack-n-slash games like God of War or Devil May Cry.

*Note: I played with an Xbox 360 controller; however the controls were still frustrating and a horrible targeting system makes force grip a chore to use.

I tried really hard to enjoy this game, I really did. I'm a fan of Star Wars, and I enjoy action games that require skill beyond mashing one button the entire game so I thought this would be a great fit.

To make this short, this game was a let down. Enemies can stun lock you by giving you a stern look, while multiple slashes with hot plasma and force attacks that could move a battleship do nothing to any foe stronger than the basic trooper. Dodgy keyboard controls add to the poor design choices, if you do play this game then a controller is highly suggested.

What finally did it in for me was the final battle. Without giving anything away, I was 1-shot by the final boss when he stuck me between himself and a corner.

To sum it up: Only get this game in a bundle or on sale, and don't get your hopes up too high.

reviewText:
When I first played this on the 360 I really had a lot of fun. I never understood the negative reviews and arbitrary hate this game recieved. That said, the PC, specifically the STEAM version has some pretty negative points that you may overlook, but I find pretty disheartening.

First off, 2 levels lose their audio partially. All you can hear is your lightasber, powers, sometimes music and stormtrooper screams as you cut them donwn. The issue is within the files downloaded from the Steam server, as retail disc versions do not have this issue. It's been 6 years since release and no official fix has been presented. You have to replace the faulty files yourself from whichever source you can get.

Aside from that, and I'm sure other reviews cover this, there's the issue with the visuals. The extent of graphics customization is limited to resolution and a check box for high detail, that's it.

If you want to enjoy the gameplay, an Xbox 360 controller is a must-have. Mouse and keyboard is very clunky and I am not aware if there is any other third party gamepad support.

As for the core game, it is fairly entertaining and challenging at parts. It does suffer from invincibility frames, enemies pulling off attacks that you cannot block and sometimes not even evade.

All in all, it is playable and a very decent game, but the technical issues are not warranted for something you paid for.

reviewText:
I'm not a huge fan of the yes/no system. Can this game be fun? Yes. Will it be frustrating? YES. Would you be missing out if you never played it? Probably not.

There's something enjoyable about this game and getting to use force powers in an excessive way. I enjoyed it on my Wii and I'm enjoying it now.

However, this game is not a very well made game. Level design is not good, enemies are either too easy or stunlock you until you die, checkpoints are not close enough together and you will ALWAYS be fighting the camera. I probably wouldn't play this without a USB gamepad. The controls are not tight at all and it's hard to get your character to do what you want him to do. You will fall off of edges a lot because the platforming is terrible. There are QTEs at the end of boss fights.

Personally, this game feels like it has a spectacle-fighter sort of vibe. Except, it lacks almost everything that makes a spectacle fighter good. If done correctly, this game could have been amazing.

The graphics are pretty good (aside from the cutscenes). But honestly, nothing dates this game more than its terrible control and camera issues.

Overall, I think the game is fun, despite its shortcomings. I would probably only get this game at a heavily discounted price though. This is a bargin-bin game (which is where I bought my Wii version). It is good fun for that kind of game. But I find myself setting the game down at least once every 30 minutes because of how frustrating it can be. Unlike something like Dark Souls, this game controls so sloppily that you do not blame yourself, you blame this poorly made game.

reviewText:
Star Wars - The Force Unleashed: PLayed through from 4/29/2015 - 5/3/2015

Star Wars - The Force Unleashed is a capable hack and slash romp through the Star Wars Universe. The story is told picking up from the end of Episode III and fills in some of the abyssmal gap between the prequel trilogy and the original trilogy.

Some fair plot twists and some darn good storytelling make this a game worth playing for any Star Wars fan. There are several familiar character cameos and some nice subtle tie in's from both trilogies. All of the characters are very well voice acted and the story elements provided me with the majority of the incentive to get through the title.

Light Saber combat is fluid and fun against most of the weaker to medium foes. However, the larger enemies and boss encounters end up being an excersize in discovery and repetition. That is, you find the bosses weakness and continually exploit it until victory is achieved. I found myself spamming force lighting for most of the game to this effect.

The control scheme did not translate well to the mouse and keyboard. I would recommend a gamepad for this title. Either a 360 or PD3 controller should do the trick. Force Grip and throw seemed to be fairly useless for the most part as my inteded throw destination was often overwritten by a completely random direction. Similarly, in the boss fights the camera postioning becomes fixed and I often found myself tossing lightning around the arena rather than at my enemy.

Some simple custimization options let the player make small changes in the protagonists appearance which is a nice touch.

In the end I would give Star Wars - The Force Unleashed a 6/10 for a casual non-star wars fan for the poor combat dynamics in the boss fights. I would award it with an 8/10 for a Star Wars Fan for a spectacular universe expanding story and tie in with some serviceable lightsaber combat.

reviewText:
It's a port from a console, and it's not a very good one either.
Default 30 fps lock, altough it can be modded to be 60 fps.
Menu navigation is not supported for mouse, and the keyboard layout cannot be changed.
Option menu is extremely limited, for changing the graphics you have to tick a single checkbox.
Menu graphics are obviously meant for consoles, but for PC screens, they're way too huge. (And a pain to navigate)

The game CAN get enjoyable at some parts, but most of the time it feels tiresome to play it. The sore need for a save after a risky, long battle can get especially tiresome, since if you die after the battle, you will be spawned back to the last checkpoint.

This especially comes up when fighting bosses. Just about to kill a boss in your last breath, but only manage to die and start it almost all over again.
Bosses are a spam to play, sometimes even outright annoying with the limited saving capabilities you have, and are sometimes even unfair. (ex. You can only hit the boss once per combo, while the boss can punch through your defences and ruthlessy spam it)

If you like QTE's you might actually like this one a lot.

TL;DR Game portrays you as a powerful jedi and falls on spam tactics and QTEs.

reviewText:
Finally finished this little gem of a game which I put off playing for sooooo long.

First of It has some issues, but nothing really game breaking (for me anyway). I loaded this up set it to full hd 1080p graphics are all set to the max, xbox 360 controller supported sat back and played away like a good little Jedi. The game ran perfectly with no major issues at all nothing game breaking, maybe a few random bad bits of level design but nothing that can't be avoided in the first place. The combat was good, a little stiff and sometimes sluggish especially when standing back up after being knocked down and then getting knocked down straight away and to have that repeat 3 or 4 times is very annoying, but not game breaking.

I had an issue on the last level of the game where my sound was missing i could hear slight lightsabre effects but everything else was missing, but this was cured when i downloaded the fixed files from the forum and took seconds to do and was easy to do.

The game itself is alright nothing spectacular it reminded me of Devil May Cry meets Star Wars, its a lot of hack and slash but with force powers and cool lightsabres. You dont use any pistols or ranged weapons other than force powers and throwing of the lightsabre, so dont expect to use rifles etc because you cant. There is a basic but effective leveling up system for your character and the force powers, you can also collect crystals for your sabre to change colour and to add perks to your weapon. These can be found through the levels and by completing various challenged throughout the game.

The game can be frustrating and sometimes lacks proper intruction but nothing major i found and completed all objectives/side missions and enjoyed doing so. One thing I would recommend is that you take breaks when playing this game i spanned it over 3 nights playing for a couple of hours at a time. I did that because its repetetive the same enemies over and over some with added powers/abilities and the odd mini boss before the inevitable end level boss.

That brings me onto the next point i had, Bosses, they didnt seem very tough at all, in fact i found the mini-boss battles with the AT-ST and others that wont be mentioned were a lot tougher at points during the game. The bosses seemed to be over in a few minutes and a lot of them were defeated the exact same way as the previous one but because they were so short i wasnt too fussed.

Now the music, the music. What can i say we all know what the Soundtrack to anything Star Wars is gonna sound like and this game does not fail in providing us with the well known star wars classics. They really do make the game feel more epic than it actually is, i was enjoying my lightsabre massacre with the epic star was soundtrack playing in tempo to the slaying of many, many clone troopers. I would say the soundtrack alone made me enjoy this game more than i should of.

Graphics - I was running it in 1080p as stated earlier with everything set the to max. It ran perfectly not graphical issues at all it looks quite nice for an old'ish game. The only issue i had was the terrible camera angles in various parts of the game but once again not game breaking.

Overall -  There is little in the way of storyline to keep you going it was ok the cutscenes were great, music spot on, graphics were good for the age of the game, QTE was a little annoying with little time to react to some. The only issue i had was with the sound glitching out on the last level but i fixed that so overall i give this game  7/10, could be better but could also be a lot worse, if you are a Star Wars fan and you also like Devil May Cry hack and slash action then this might be the game for you, just dont expect next gen gaming physics or graphics, but what you do get is a few hours of fun.

reviewText:
Star Wars - The Force Unleashed: PLayed through from 4/29/2015 - 5/3/2015

Star Wars - The Force Unleashed is a capable hack and slash romp through the Star Wars Universe. The story is told picking up from the end of Episode III and fills in some of the abyssmal gap between the prequel trilogy and the original trilogy.

Some fair plot twists and some darn good storytelling make this a game worth playing for any Star Wars fan. There are several familiar character cameos and some nice subtle tie in's from both trilogies. All of the characters are very well voice acted and the story elements provided me with the majority of the incentive to get through the title.

Light Saber combat is fluid and fun against most of the weaker to medium foes. However, the larger enemies and boss encounters end up being an excersize in discovery and repetition. That is, you find the bosses weakness and continually exploit it until victory is achieved. I found myself spamming force lighting for most of the game to this effect.

The control scheme did not translate well to the mouse and keyboard. I would recommend a gamepad for this title. Either a 360 or PD3 controller should do the trick. Force Grip and throw seemed to be fairly useless for the most part as my inteded throw destination was often overwritten by a completely random direction. Similarly, in the boss fights the camera postioning becomes fixed and I often found myself tossing lightning around the arena rather than at my enemy.

Some simple custimization options let the player make small changes in the protagonists appearance which is a nice touch.

In the end I would give Star Wars - The Force Unleashed a 6/10 for a casual non-star wars fan for the poor combat dynamics in the boss fights. I would award it with an 8/10 for a Star Wars Fan for a spectacular universe expanding story and tie in with some serviceable lightsaber combat.

reviewText:
Combat system has one hell of a learning curve. This isn't some button masher where you can just swing your lightsaber to victory. You need to think strategically about each move you make.

Enemies can take a nasty chunk of you health away if you aren't playing correctly, and it's just a struggle until you actually start using the good force which aren't all that intuitive nor are they always reliable. Force push controls sometimes fly objects off in directions you didn't want, and the camera angles are just bad, especially boss fights.

I would say that in this game, there wasn't a single boss fight I enjoyed. Every one of them was just annoying. As enemies can begin to block your attacks mid combo but you can't do the same to them....so if they hit you once they may as hit you 2-4 more times for a massive lost in health due to the ragdoll mechanics.

I found myself stunned in ragdoll mode many many times due to be hit by an offscreen projectile...remember those camera angles I mentioned earlier?

Story: 8/10
Combat: 3/10 (camera angles, ragdoll physics, overpowered AI, and annoying stuns, just kills the combat system)


I'd rate this game 4/10

Not exactly what you would have expected from a Star Wars game. To the most part it IS fun, the first couple times it can be rewarding if you get a given combo right, but on the long run, it's pretty boring and let me tell you, the controls are CLUNKY.

The way they've decided to do the targeting feels absolutely horrible on PC. Get into the menus and you'll see why: this is a console port, and one of the worst kinds in that. Press [ and ] to change between menus? WHAT??

Also you'll notice that there's barely any graphics settings. Keep in mind, this game is fairly old, and not very demanding hardware-wise, but it still won't run over 30 FPS.

The game contains quite a few QTEs, which you either are or are not a fan of. I personally loathe them, some people probably like them, but it just slows the pace of the game down - and at some points, the controls are horrible, as mentioned in the next paragraph.

So, like some people I got this from the Humble Bundle where this was was a tier 3. Now I though that for some reason that this would be better than the ps3 version which I had (and though it was boring). Little did I know that even with unofficial files to help make the game more playable, the game is still broken.

Most of you probably didn't have the same issue I had but I'm gonna say what issues I had.
1. When the game starts up, on the battle of  Kashyyk, the audio started off EXTREMELY off balance. You could barely hear either voices or music thanks to the sound effects and this was all on normal settings in the audio option
2. When facing the jedi as vader, the camera is locked away from where the battle suppose to be, making it difficult to actually see what's happening (I beat him, he's not ment to be hard anyways)
3. This is more of the issue from the fps unlocker but some reason you'd constantly levetate anything upwards, making the use of the force annoying
4. The break on the cammel's back, When fighting the jedi on the space station, the audio gave up and just died. Literally it gave up and no audio was coming out. I though there was something wrong with my hardware but it turns out it wasn't cause a cutscene to interrupt the boss fight played and there were sound.

Yea, I rage quit afte that but after seeing this kind of problem, I should have known that playing this on the pc would be a bad idea to the point I'm pretty scared to see how the 2nd game (Force Unleashed II) would perform if the first game had this slew of problems.

I really don't recommend this game to anyone unless you are covered in good luck to not run into this landfill of bugs.

reviewText:
Star Wars - The Force Unleashed: PLayed through from 4/29/2015 - 5/3/2015

Star Wars - The Force Unleashed is a capable hack and slash romp through the Star Wars Universe. The story is told picking up from the end of Episode III and fills in some of the abyssmal gap between the prequel trilogy and the original trilogy.

Some fair plot twists and some darn good storytelling make this a game worth playing for any Star Wars fan. There are several familiar character cameos and some nice subtle tie in's from both trilogies. All of the characters are very well voice acted and the story elements provided me with the majority of the incentive to get through the title.

Light Saber combat is fluid and fun against most of the weaker to medium foes. However, the larger enemies and boss encounters end up being an excersize in discovery and repetition. That is, you find the bosses weakness and continually exploit it until victory is achieved. I found myself spamming force lighting for most of the game to this effect.

The control scheme did not translate well to the mouse and keyboard. I would recommend a gamepad for this title. Either a 360 or PD3 controller should do the trick. Force Grip and throw seemed to be fairly useless for the most part as my inteded throw destination was often overwritten by a completely random direction. Similarly, in the boss fights the camera postioning becomes fixed and I often found myself tossing lightning around the arena rather than at my enemy.

Some simple custimization options let the player make small changes in the protagonists appearance which is a nice touch.

In the end I would give Star Wars - The Force Unleashed a 6/10 for a casual non-star wars fan for the poor combat dynamics in the boss fights. I would award it with an 8/10 for a Star Wars Fan for a spectacular universe expanding story and tie in with some serviceable lightsaber combat.

reviewText: The ultimate power fantasy! If you're wanting to let off some steam, this is the perfect game for you. If you're looking for a challenging game, look somewhere else. This game is super easy. All enimies are no match against you (bosses can go by faster than you can blink) and a lot of collectables stick out like a sore thumb. As for the story line; this game explains what happened between episodes 3 and 4 with an alternate timeline that has you dominating Tatooine and Hoth. Wheather you like it or not is up to you.\n\nOverall the game is fun but lacks the difficulty that makes games enjoyable.

reviewText:
Solid Charachter Action Game set before A New Hope. Pretty simple for it's genre but it's really fun and the PC version is the definitive version as long as you installed the 60fps patch and the sound fix.

Visuals were really nice and the art was really well done.

Sound was absolutely fantastic, all the lightsaber sounds were perfect along with a really great soundtrack.

Gameplay is a bit simple but fun regardless.

7.5/10
